author: Oliver Smith
title: Escape the rain with Eurostar fares from £32
text: Britons can secure rail tickets to France and Belgium for as little as £32 from tomorrow as Eurostar launches a 13-day sale. Standard fares for Paris, Brussels and Lille start at £32 one-way, for Lyon they cost from £40, while for Avignon and Marseille they start at £45. Travel to any Belgium station beyond Brussels, including Bruges, Ghent and Antwerp, costs from £35. There are savings to be had on Standard Premier fares too, with rates ranging from £85 to £95 each way. The tickets entitle travellers to more spacious seats and a light meal. The sale takes place from August 27 – September 8 and is valid for travel until December 16 for Paris, Lille, Calais and Belgian stations, or until April 25, 2016, for destinations farther south. Nick Trend, Telegraph Travel's consumer editor, said: “Eurostar’s cheapest tickets sell out well in advance - especially to Paris. These fares - which offer even better value - are likely to go even more quickly. The fare to Lyon, which now has regular direct services from London, looks particularly attractive.” • Eurostar to launch direct service to Amsterdam • Flight, ferry or train - which is the best way to get to France? • Eurostar at 20: two decades of the cross-channel operator Avignon Photo: AP/FOTOLIA Paris needs no introduction, being one of the most beautiful and cultured cities in the world – and a favourite with British travellers. Handsome Lille has elegant shops and lively markets; Lyon is France’s capital of gastronomy. Strategically situated high above the river Rhône and encircled by medieval ramparts, Avignon 's is a warren of cobbled streets, lantern-lit passageways and architectural treasures. • How Eurostar revolutionised travel to France • What now for Eurostar? • Will Wi-Fi ruin trips on Eurostar? Once gritty Marseille has been revitalised by new designer hotels, galleries, chic restaurants and enough shops to fill a year’s-worth of lifestyle magazines. Over the border in Belgium, Brussels has fine food and a “rough-edged character and bubbling conviviality”, according to our expert, Antwerp is “one of the most culturally fascinating and under-appreciated cities in Europe”, Ghent is an historic port where beer and bicycles reign, and Bruges is “an almost perfect medieval ensemble of canals, churches, squares and cobbled streets”. Brussels Photo: AP/FOTOLIA Eurostar tickets for the ski season went on sale last month . Its direct high-speed service to the French Alps stops at Moûtier, Aime La Plagne and Bourg-Saint-Maurice to provide access to resorts such as Courchevel , Méribel , Les Arcs and La Plagne . Services to Lyon put passengers within easy reach of other French resorts, such as Alpe d'Huez and Les Deux Alpes . For those looking to travel to the Swiss Alps, Eurostar has introduced a service to Geneva via Lille, with trains timed to make the connection as smooth and efficient as possible. From Geneva, a huge number of ski resorts are easily reached, including Les Arcs, La Plagne, Tignes and Val d'Isère . To buy tickets visit www.eurostar.com or call 03432 186 186.
